Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

hashtag#Hiring hashtag#W2 hashtag#FulltimeSite Reliability Engineer (SRE)Location: Seattle – HybridWe are seeking a highly skilled Site Reliability Engineer (SRE) with a strong software engineering background to join our team. This role is central to building and operating reliable, scalable, and performant systems while applying software development practices to infrastructure and operations. As an SRE, you will collaborate closely with engineering teams to design and develop solutions that improve reliability, accelerate delivery, and reduce manual effort. Role & Responsibility: ·      Design and develop software solutions to improve system reliability, scalability, and maintainability.·      Write and maintain high-quality, testable code in languages like Python, Go, Java, or similar.·      Build self-healing systems and automation tools to minimize human intervention.·      Collaborate with software engineers to design robust, scalable systems with reliability in mind.·      Ensure systems meet SLOs and SLAs through thoughtful architecture and automation.·      Participate in capacity planning and system design reviews.·      Create and maintain tools to automate manual processes, streamline deployments, and enhance monitoring.·      Continuously innovate by implementing software engineering practices into operational tasks.·      Debug and resolve complex production issues using software debugging techniques.·      Conduct postmortems and implement long-term fixes for recurring issues.·      Develop robust observability solutions, including logging, monitoring, and alerting.·      Build dashboards and reporting tools to provide actionable insights into system performance and customer-centric KPIs.·      Work closely with development teams to incorporate reliability best practices into the software lifecycle.·      Advocate for engineering solutions that enhance both product features and system reliability. Required Qualifications ·      Bachelor's degree in Computer Science, Software Engineering, or a related field, or equivalent practical experience.·      10+ years of professional experience as a software engineer or SRE with a focus on software development.·      Strong programming skills in one or more languages, such as Python, Go, Java, C++, or similar.·      Experience designing and implementing distributed systems and high-performance applications.·      Proficiency with infrastructure-as-code tools (e.g., Terraform, Ansible) and cloud platforms (AWS, GCP, or Azure).·      Expertise in containerization and orchestration tools (e.g., Docker, Kubernetes). Nice to have ·      Gen AI Scripting experience·      Should have experience using these platforms --https://www.nobl9.com/ -- https://lnkd.in/gP-ErCxi·      We want SREs to write code to automate mundane + repetitive tasks as opposed to just writing alerts and monitors

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

This role is central to building and operating reliable, scalable, and performant systems while applying software development practices to infrastructure and operations. As an SRE, you will collaborate closely with engineering teams to design and develop solutions that improve reliability, accelerate delivery, and reduce manual effort. Role & Responsibility: ·      Design and develop software solutions to improve system reliability, scalability, and maintainability.·      Write and maintain high-quality, testable code in languages like Python, Go, Java, or similar.·      Build self-healing systems and automation tools to minimize human intervention.·      Collaborate with software engineers to design robust, scalable systems with reliability in mind.·      Ensure systems meet SLOs and SLAs through thoughtful architecture and automation.·      Participate in capacity planning and system design reviews.·      Create and maintain tools to automate manual processes, streamline deployments, and enhance monitoring.·      Continuously innovate by implementing software engineering practices into operational tasks.·      Debug and resolve complex production issues using software debugging techniques.·      Conduct postmortems and implement long-term fixes for recurring issues.·      Develop robust observability solutions, including logging, monitoring, and alerting.·      Build dashboards and reporting tools to provide actionable insights into system performance and customer-centric KPIs.·      Work closely with development teams to incorporate reliability best practices into the software lifecycle.·      Advocate for engineering solutions that enhance both product features and system reliability. Required Qualifications ·      Bachelor's degree in Computer Science, Software Engineering, or a related field, or equivalent practical experience.·      10+ years of professional experience as a software engineer or SRE with a focus on software development.·      Strong programming skills in one or more languages, such as Python, Go, Java, C++, or similar.·      Experience designing and implementing distributed systems and high-performance applications.·      Proficiency with infrastructure-as-code tools (e.g., Terraform, Ansible) and cloud platforms (AWS, GCP, or Azure).·      Expertise in containerization and orchestration tools (e.g., Docker, Kubernetes). Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. This role is central to building and operating reliable, scalable, and performant systems while applying software development practices to infrastructure and operations. As an SRE, you will collaborate closely with engineering teams to design and develop solutions that improve reliability, accelerate delivery, and reduce manual effort. Role & Responsibility: ·      Design and develop software solutions to improve system reliability, scalability, and maintainability.·      Write and maintain high-quality, testable code in languages like Python, Go, Java, or similar.·      Build self-healing systems and automation tools to minimize human intervention.·      Collaborate with software engineers to design robust, scalable systems with reliability in mind.·      Ensure systems meet SLOs and SLAs through thoughtful architecture and automation.·      Participate in capacity planning and system design reviews.·      Create and maintain tools to automate manual processes, streamline deployments, and enhance monitoring.·      Continuously innovate by implementing software engineering practices into operational tasks.·      Debug and resolve complex production issues using software debugging techniques.·      Conduct postmortems and implement long-term fixes for recurring issues.·      Develop robust observability solutions, including logging, monitoring, and alerting.·      Build dashboards and reporting tools to provide actionable insights into system performance and customer-centric KPIs.·      Work closely with development teams to incorporate reliability best practices into the software lifecycle.·      Advocate for engineering solutions that enhance both product features and system reliability. Required Qualifications ·      Bachelor's degree in Computer Science, Software Engineering, or a related field, or equivalent practical experience.·      10+ years of professional experience as a software engineer or SRE with a focus on software development.·      Strong programming skills in one or more languages, such as Python, Go, Java, C++, or similar.·      Experience designing and implementing distributed systems and high-performance applications.·      Proficiency with infrastructure-as-code tools (e.g., Terraform, Ansible) and cloud platforms (AWS, GCP, or Azure).·      Expertise in containerization and orchestration tools (e.g., Docker, Kubernetes). Nice to have ·      Gen AI Scripting experience·      Should have experience using these platforms --https://www.nobl9.com/ -- https://lnkd.in/gP-ErCxi·      We want SREs to write code to automate mundane + repetitive tasks as opposed to just writing alerts and monitors

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

This role is central to building and operating reliable, scalable, and performant systems while applying software development practices to infrastructure and operations. As an SRE, you will collaborate closely with engineering teams to design and develop solutions that improve reliability, accelerate delivery, and reduce manual effort. Role & Responsibility: ·      Design and develop software solutions to improve system reliability, scalability, and maintainability.·      Write and maintain high-quality, testable code in languages like Python, Go, Java, or similar.·      Build self-healing systems and automation tools to minimize human intervention.·      Collaborate with software engineers to design robust, scalable systems with reliability in mind.·      Ensure systems meet SLOs and SLAs through thoughtful architecture and automation.·      Participate in capacity planning and system design reviews.·      Create and maintain tools to automate manual processes, streamline deployments, and enhance monitoring.·      Continuously innovate by implementing software engineering practices into operational tasks.·      Debug and resolve complex production issues using software debugging techniques.·      Conduct postmortems and implement long-term fixes for recurring issues.·      Develop robust observability solutions, including logging, monitoring, and alerting.·      Build dashboards and reporting tools to provide actionable insights into system performance and customer-centric KPIs.·      Work closely with development teams to incorporate reliability best practices into the software lifecycle.·      Advocate for engineering solutions that enhance both product features and system reliability. Required Qualifications ·      Bachelor's degree in Computer Science, Software Engineering, or a related field, or equivalent practical experience.·      10+ years of professional experience as a software engineer or SRE with a focus on software development.·      Strong programming skills in one or more languages, such as Python, Go, Java, C++, or similar.·      Experience designing and implementing distributed systems and high-performance applications.·      Proficiency with infrastructure-as-code tools (e.g., Terraform, Ansible) and cloud platforms (AWS, GCP, or Azure).·      Expertise in containerization and orchestration tools (e.g., Docker, Kubernetes). Nice to have ·      Gen AI Scripting experience·      Should have experience using these platforms --https://www.nobl9.com/ -- https://lnkd.in/gP-ErCxi·      We want SREs to write code to automate mundane + repetitive tasks as opposed to just writing alerts and monitors

Navigating Global Opportunities: A Lesson in TransparencyOver the past few months, I’ve actively pursued global roles, investing significant time and effort into the process—completing case studies, preparing presentations, and going through multiple rounds of interviews. In several instances, I successfully qualified for the final rounds, only to be met with an unexpected hurdle at the offer stage: the preference for a local candidate to avoid visa sponsorship and additional liabilities or some limited sponsorships quota or whatever.While I completely understand the operational and financial constraints companies face, such policies should be communicated at the beginning of the hiring process. Clear expectations help both candidates and hiring teams avoid unnecessary time investment and frustration. If visa sponsorship isn’t a possibility due to some xyz reasons, it’s only fair to be upfront about it from the start.To those navigating similar experiences—keep pushing forward. Every challenge is a stepping stone to the right opportunity!

ATTENTION🚨I've been searching for a job as a fresher for over six months using various job sites like Internshala, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Unstop. Despite applying to many roles, I haven't received any responses from HRs, which has been frustrating and discouraging.Every day I wake up with the hope of landing an interview, only to be told I'm either overqualified or lack the necessary experience. Applying to numerous roles and dealing with imposter syndrome has been exhausting.Moreover, I've noticed that LinkedIn is now filled with misleading job postings. Fake recruiters often share links from other platforms like Unstop instead of direct application links. Some posts ask you to "write your name and email in the comment section" or "drop your email in the comment box" for exam links or shortlist notifications, but these often turn out to be scams.Even when freshers are hired, the compensation offered is usually very low, despite the high cost of their education. Are these job postings even real? Are freshers getting hired at all? Why do HRs ask candidates to use hashtags like hashtag#interested in job postings if they don't even check profiles?Every company provides training for new employees, so why not give freshers a chance? They have the potential to excel with proper training and hard work. Freshers need genuine opportunities, not more pressure.If you've had similar experiences or have any tips, please share your thoughts in the comments below. Let's support each other in navigating this challenging job market. Good luck to everyone. hashtag#ithashtag#internship hashtag#needjob

hashtag#Hiring hashtag#W2 hashtag#FulltimeSite Reliability Engineer (SRE)Location: Seattle – HybridWe are seeking a highly skilled Site Reliability Engineer (SRE) with a strong software engineering background to join our team. This role is central to building and operating reliable, scalable, and performant systems while applying software development practices to infrastructure and operations. As an SRE, you will collaborate closely with engineering teams to design and develop solutions that improve reliability, accelerate delivery, and reduce manual effort. Role & Responsibility: ·      Design and develop software solutions to improve system reliability, scalability, and maintainability.·      Write and maintain high-quality, testable code in languages like Python, Go, Java, or similar.·      Build self-healing systems and automation tools to minimize human intervention.·      Collaborate with software engineers to design robust, scalable systems with reliability in mind.·      Ensure systems meet SLOs and SLAs through thoughtful architecture and automation.·      Participate in capacity planning and system design reviews.·      Create and maintain tools to automate manual processes, streamline deployments, and enhance monitoring.·      Continuously innovate by implementing software engineering practices into operational tasks.·      Debug and resolve complex production issues using software debugging techniques.·      Conduct postmortems and implement long-term fixes for recurring issues.·      Develop robust observability solutions, including logging, monitoring, and alerting.·      Build dashboards and reporting tools to provide actionable insights into system performance and customer-centric KPIs.·      Work closely with development teams to incorporate reliability best practices into the software lifecycle.·      Advocate for engineering solutions that enhance both product features and system reliability. Required Qualifications ·      Bachelor's degree in Computer Science, Software Engineering, or a related field, or equivalent practical experience.·      10+ years of professional experience as a software engineer or SRE with a focus on software development.·      Strong programming skills in one or more languages, such as Python, Go, Java, C++, or similar.·      Experience designing and implementing distributed systems and high-performance applications.·      Proficiency with infrastructure-as-code tools (e.g., Terraform, Ansible) and cloud platforms (AWS, GCP, or Azure).·      Expertise in containerization and orchestration tools (e.g., Docker, Kubernetes). Nice to have ·      Gen AI Scripting experience·      Should have experience using these platforms --https://www.nobl9.com/ -- https://lnkd.in/gP-ErCxi·      We want SREs to write code to automate mundane + repetitive tasks as opposed to just writing alerts and monitors
